Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: Advancing the Accessibility of Data for Behavioral Research in the 21st Century; Ithaca, NY - Summer, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
The digital era has created new opportunities for data storage and access, leading to an atmosphere and expectation for open data sharing that will benefit the broader scientific community. For the field of animal behavior, data sharing and access presents a range of challenges due to the collection and use of numerous data types, the need to address standards, and a common strategy for archiving some key data types. For example, audiovisual recordings require substantial "hands on" time for processing, large storage capacity for large files, rich descriptive metadata, and constant migration to new formats as technologies change. As a consequence, these behavioral data remain prohibitively under-curated and broadly inaccessible to the biological research community. Yet, at the same time, biologists and other researchers are collecting vast amounts of such data, and this trend is increasing as recording technologies become more sophisticated and inexpensive. These data will remain generally inaccessible if the challenges of archiving digital media are not addressed.

This award funds a workshop to be held at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology in 2016. The meeting will bring together experts from a number of relevant fields to discuss preservation and accessibility of samples relevant to research on animal behavior and physiology. Representatives and experts from several stakeholder communities will come together to document the challenges of making behavioral data broadly accessible, and to develop a framework that prioritizes the key issues. Outcomes will be published in a white paper and a formal publication. The meeting will be relevant to the development of methods and approaches to citizen science projects that emphasize the use of digital media. Graduate students and postdocs will participate in the meeting itself, providing a valuable experience and enhancing their training and background in data archiving and accessibility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The digital era has created new opportunities for data storage and access, leading to an atmosphere and expectation for open data sharing that will benefit the broader scientific community. These opportunities bring with them new challenges as well, and these challenges can vary across data types and disciplines. The field of animal behavior, for example, relies heavily on digital media (i.e., audio/video recordings and still images of animals engaged in behavioral acts), physiological samples/data, neuronal data from free-living animals, and a number of other data types. These data types are critically important for broad scale comparative studies, yet they raise numerous challenges for data archiving and accessibility. For example, audiovisual recordings require substantial “hands on” time for processing, large storage capacity for large files, rich descriptive metadata, and constant migration to new formats as technologies change. Standards and best practices have not been widely discussed or adopted for such behavioral data, and most existing data archives and biological research collections lack the expertise and infrastructure for it. As a consequence, these behavioral data remain prohibitively under-curated and broadly inaccessible to the biological research community. Yet, at the same time, biologists and other researchers are collecting vast amounts of such data, and this trend is increasing as recording and other technologies become more sophisticated and inexpensive. These data will remain generally inaccessible, and likely will be lost, if the challenges of archiving digital media are not addressed. 

 

This award brought together 37 key representatives and experts (including several early career professionals) from several stakeholder communities, in two separate workshops, to discuss these issues and consider explicitly the challenges of archiving behavioral data for the biological sciences. The key points and recommendations that emerged from these discussions are being written up in an opinion paper to be published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, and also will be included in a white paper to be submitted to NSF. This report will not provide answers to all of the issues raised, but rather will develop a framework that identifies and prioritizes the key issues and make recommendations for the most important next steps. This report will be a key step toward finding sustainable solutions. Moreover, although some of the issues addressed will be unique to behavioral data, others will be more broadly relevant to other data types, such that solutions for these data can help inform approaches to archiving other data types and vice versa. Finally, this paper will help inform the broader research community of both the power and the challenges of working with audiovisual and other types of behavioral data.

 

The white paper and peer-reviewed publication that resulted from the workshops will serve as a guide for future development of data archival capacity, and as such will have clear and long lasting impacts on the broader research community. Indeed, many of the issues discussed, and recommendations made, will be relevant to forms of scientific data beyond animal behavior (and vice versa). In addition to its value to the professional research community, behavioral data and techniques have enormous potential for broader public engagement. Finally, the issues addressed in the proposed meeting will be relevant to the development of methods and approaches to citizen science projects that emphasize the use of digital media.
